The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

I did not go to office hours, so I did not interact with the TAs.
Coco
The teaching assistants were extremely unapproachable. I was in touch with Coco most because she graded my papers, but their hours were difficult.
Both were equally good and very helpful.
I did not interact with the TAs
Avishesh Neupane
I worked with both Coco and Emily.
Instructor: Emily Elizabeth Oldfield  I also interacted with Avishesh Neupane, after he came on board.

Instructor: Emily Elizabeth Oldfield  Emily
Instructor: Emily Elizabeth Oldfield  Emily was very helpful when I visited office hours.
Instructor: Emily Elizabeth Oldfield  Emily was great, very helpful and accessible.

Instructor: Emily Elizabeth Oldfield  Emily was available and knowledgeable!
Instructor: Emily Elizabeth Oldfield  Very helpful!

Instructor: Jia Liu  Coco was excellent in explaining the homework and the course material. She also was very responsive in any question that I had for my homework.

Instructor: Jia Liu  Coco Liu
Instructor: Jia Liu  Coco Jia Liu

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I LOVED this class! Jonathan is the best stats professor I have ever had. I have tried various stats classes over the years, at various universities, and Jonathan is by far the ONLY statistics professor who makes the subject intuitive.This class was invaluable to me, and will be useful to anyone who wants to do quantitative research. I highly recommend it to everybody. The professor is very approachable, and very knowledgeable about the subject material.
Professor is very engaging and clear, and is quick to take a different explanatory approach if students get stuck
Jonathan delivers great and energetic lectures that make the subject more interesting than it would otherwise be.

I would recommend Jonathan Reuning-scherer's class for anyone who needs a foundational understanding of statistics especially if you've had negative experiences with math and stats in the past. I also recommend his class as a brush up if you've been away from the tools for a while. His methods stray from conventional and it's exactly what the doctor ordered!

Prof R-S is very hardworking and genuinely wants to help people learn. He comes to class prepared, energetic, and creates an interactive dynamic to process material. He is accommodating for students and always tried to connect concepts to practical examples.I think the notes pages that he created are incredibly helpful.Coco basically for the first half of the course gave us the answers to the homeworks in the TA sessions. Then she redesigned her approach to respond to student questions - I ended up learning a lot more.
The instructor is truly great, but the rhythm of the class is extremely fast, and key concepts are lost.
N/A

I thought JDRS was fantastic: more than most other profs I've had at Yale, he really went out if the way to make himself accessible to students. I don't know how he managed to make time to work with all the students on our projects, but he did! I thought his teaching style was generally great: I appreciated how he paid attention to the mood of the class and slowed down, etc. if we needed it.That said, I do wish we had actually had a required textbook, and have had our problem sets from a book. I know that's a bit boring, but I often felt myself unsure where to look if I got stuck on a homework problem. It would have been nice to have our Psets match a book that we could use for reference, and it would have also helped to be able to do similar problems that weren't assigned and check our answers (the odd or even numbered questions in a book that usually have the answers). Overall fantastic class though!
This course was very valuable for gaining an understanding of the statistical tools to analyze data. JDRS is a very engaging lecturer and kept class interesting.
excellent class, excellent professor.

Professor Reuning-Scherer made Statistics fun and more interesting than I would imagine a standard Stats class to be. My one complaint would be with his office hours. People would sign up online but no one abided by the rules, including him. I would have liked more one-on-one time with him wihtout the fear of another student needing his help. In the future, it would be beneficial to his students if he had an equal number of "drop-in" hours where anyone could come by and meetings with his students that people had to sign up for.
Very useful to all of us irrespective of our academic background.

I got really lost during lectures sometimes. I'm not sure that it's in his best interest to just keep trudging along after we're not able to answer any of his questions anymore. I wish we could simplify things a little more and not rely as much on reading through the notes. Minitab examples helped a lot.

Question 4: Although Professor JDRS was excellent, he tended to cover concepts a bit too fast. Students were generally able to keep up, but when it came to more complex concepts, it was more difficult to follow.

Question 4: I liked the sense of momentum in this class. The professor did not get bogged down in excessive detail, and challenging concepts seemed less so due to the pace with which we moved through them. However, in some cases it would have been helpful to slow down and deal with the painstaking concepts more fully.

The class was very well structured, the homework was linked to the lectures, and the professor was always available for questions. Excellent class! The teaching assistants were not very committed to the class and during office hours were more willing to give us the answers rather than to explain the problems to us. I think that next time around the TAs should be chosen more carefully.

JDRS is incredibly accessible, approachable, dedicated to the course, and understands the needs of the students! I really wanted to take this class--wanted the tools to approach my dataset!!--and even so, it exceeded my expectations

Prof. Reuning-Scherer is a talented and dedicated professor. The course covered too much material for most students and could be pared down some. It's unclear if the material will be useful to me in the future. Overall it is a very good intro to stats class.

The main issue for me was the pace of the course. When I was able to understand the material, it was really useful, but towards the last few weeks of the semester, either the pace increased, and/or the difficulty of the material did, and I really struggled to keep up (despite re-reading the notes, trying to decipher my textbook, etc.) So, the instruction was really useful, but very fast. This increased my frustration with office hours, where the TAs were doing their best to quickly get around to everyone, and more detailed explanations of the material (versus quicker questions about the homework) didn't seem as possible.

The professor is extremely approachable and keeps students entertained with a great sense of humor. However, I felt that sometimes the lectures moved too fast- especially the section on probability. I would either devote another week to probability or remove it from the class altogether. Or, alternatively, assign students problems that are a bit easier / rudimentary. Having finished the course, I do not feel I have a strong grasp of the material. Having said that, I'm not sure that this is the point of an intro-level stats class. I have come to the conclusion that most learning in stats comes from doing lots of applications/homeworks. The class would be better if it were limited to say 25 students or so, so as to give more individualized student attention during lectures.

Prof. Reuning-Scherer is one of the best professors I have had in my Yale career. He knew the material so well and knew the best methods to teach the material to new statisticians. I was always energized in class because he was and he kept his audience engaged in every way he could. His review games were very helpful and appreciated and I think he is an incredible educator.
Maybe place the textbooks on reserve at CSSSI? I ended up checking one out (and using it!), but I felt badly for depriving other students access to the book.

We covered a lot of material in the class and it could be difficult to keep up. The main challenge for me was understanding the reasoning behind why we were using a type of analysis. JDRS is great at making stats engaging, but it could get overly campy, and I found it frustrating when we heard "but you don't really need to know why we do this" over and over again. I respected the fact that you'd need to skim over things to cover the amount of material we did, but at the same time, it was frustrating to cover so much and yet not feel like we had enough time to really delve into why you would use the different tools.

The professor, Jonathan Ruening-Scherer, is an excellent professor. he made himself available through almost all means possible: email, cell-phone (text or call) and I believe even skype. He held numerous office hours and often extended them past their durations when students like myself had additional questions. Very reasonable, understanding professor and good at making complex subjects more digestible and easy to understand. I really give this guy my highest ratings, he helped me a lot through this class and with good lecture and I wish I had gone to his office hours more frequently. My only complaint is that the course moved too fast; it covered too much in one semester and I'm not sure that I've been able to absorb enough of the information this way. This class might be more practical if it was spread over two semesters.

I think I would have internalized more information and taken away more from the class had there been more working time in class, instead of just lectures where students were simply recipients of information.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The professor was probably the best I've had at FES (I'm a second year so I've had a few). He took potentially dull material and made it entertaining and understandable, had tons of office hours, and was very responsive via email. I learned a lot and I really credit Reuning-Scherer with helping me understand what I'm doing and why. I took stats as an undergraduate and learned how to do things by hand and more of the mathematical theory, but I really didn't appreciate the wide world of methodologies or the what-to-use-when questions. This course was great.
Engaging lecture that did not take the form of many math/stats classes of droning on and on. The style works.
The lecture is clearly outlined. The instructor is very engaging and he has a very good understanding of the material.
JDRS teaching style
Jonathan Reuning-Scherer is amazing at making statistics intuitive.
The instructor and his teaching style!
Lecture

The weekly problem sets are critical for understanding the concepts! Even though I never felt like I was doing anything properly or even understanding why I was doing what I was doing, it would turn out that I wasn't as poorly off as I felt!
The professor is AMAZING. Statistics is super boring but he made it sound fabulous. Cannot express that enough.
If you have data that you care about, the final project is a really great opportunity to apply what you learned in class.
The in-class explanations, office hours with TAs and the instructor and the notes.
Jonathan is incredible accessible, willing to help, and energetic. He makes learning statistics a great experience.

I learned more in the outside help sessions than in class. There are so many people for me it was tough to connect with the information, especially when I could just read the notes solo. That said, my comprehension of the material from solo reading of the notes pages was not sufficient. The office hours, TA sessions, and Q&A were awesome though to fill in gaps. This is more a comment on my learning style than the quality of the teaching. Prof R-S is impressive and dedicated and very smart.
Motivating, entertaining instructor.Running regression models is fun.
Clear and organized structure. Knew what to expect walking in the doors each day.

This course helped familiarize me with the basic terms and concepts of statistical analysis, which will be helpful in my research.The best parts of the course were OF COURSE when Jonathan tells crazy stories to help us remember concepts.

The best aspects from this course were the in class quiz and home work. They were very effective for me to apprehend the materials from the class. By having the quiz, I was able to review the course material in class. By having the home work, I was able to learn and think more on the material out side the class. They were also very effective to help me doing my exams.
Professor Reuning-Scherer is an engaging instructor who manages to make statistics entertaining.

The ability to use any dataset as your final project was very valuable. I was able to analyze my undergraduate thesis data with very useful input from Professor Reuning-Scherer, which helped me simultaneously learn the statistical tools and move forward with my data analysis.

Learning how to interpret statistics reported in scientific journals and learning what stats analysis I should use in my research project. It's probably not until the last half to last quarter of the class where you starting learning stuff applicable to research, so hang in there!
The class in a whole unit, all the aspect were good, particularly the homeworks which keep you reading and understanding the concepts
Clear explanation, examples, and applicability.
Being able to do/understand basic statistical analyses in one semester.
his notes for each class.
Learning with my class mates esp. the homework
The homework was frustrating but integral to my learning
Course covered a wide breadth of subjects, and managed to delve deep into the more difficult concepts.
Really helpful material, presented in a clear way: Jonathan is a great teacher, very animated and makes this material really interesting. I always enjoyed coming to class.
Professor Reuning-Scherer's enthusiastic teaching, everyday applicability, final project
A very good introduction course to statistics. A lot of examples and interesting explanation. Students are engaged.
Excellent pedagogy, professor made himself available for students.

Jonathan made learning statistics easy to understand, accessible and a fun process.It provided students taking the class with a broad overview of statistics knowledge which is essential for research work.

Jonathan is an engaging teacher and makes every effort to make class fun and use interesting examples. It was a rare class when I didn't laugh at one of his jokes. Regarding the material, I thought having weekly problem sets really kept me up to speed on the material so by the end of the course, I at least knew where to find everything if I needed to use an analysis for my final project.
The class notes were extremely well organized and clear and the problem sets were very relevant and helpful.
Instructor was engaging and fun and made the material very accessible for people like me who had been out of school for a while.
The professor's attitude. The humor, speed, and animation with which the course was taught made it much more enjoyable than it would have otherwise been.
the notes were extremely helpful, the lectures were very clear and entertaining which made learning easier... the professor has an excellent teaching style.
Lectures were engaging and interesting; professor incredibly friendly and accessible (and knowledgeable, with advice and strategies he provided for thinking about the material was perfectly on-point)
Jonathan is a very engaging professor, and the problem sets were great to explore the material. He struck a very good balance in challenging students and in keep the course relatively low-stress.
The final project was really fun and helpful for learning to apply the concepts we'd learned in class. I really enjoyed learning to use Minitab, and have already used it in other courses.
Lectures and homework.

Prof. Reuning-Scherer is excellent and makes statistics accessible to all students, including those who have not previously studied statistics. He is an engaging lecturer and integrates games and humor into classes. The material is useful and applicable across FES classes.
The problem sets were definitely helpful for understanding the material. I also liked when we went through some of the processes (regression) in class.
Very fun lectures!
Very entertaining lectures and detailed notes; Professor is very responsive despite an insanely busy schedule.
The notes were amazingly detailed and helpful. And Prof. Reuning-Sherer was animated during class and excited about the material, which kept us interested and ready to learn.
The professor is very clear and engaging. Office hours were extremely helpful.

JDRS is very engaging and I'm really glad I now have a better understanding of what goes on behind the numbers. Having the slides as a reference was also really helpful, though I think that prodding the class to do more reading would be helpful!
The quality of the professor's skills and his availability
Lecture notes are valuable as a reference
The instructor was excellent and made the lectures enjoyable and worthwhile. This course gave me a basic understanding of statistics.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The probability section was challenging and I'm still not sure I understand every aspect, but it was a small, insignificant blip in retrospect.
maybe just slow down a tad and use the entire class period instead of burning through it and ending 20 min early.
I need some push to review the lecture material after each class.
Sometimes the equations are not as well explained as they could be.
None.
Too much material in too little time - but that's the nature of it.
Phrasing of homework questions (occasionally wasn't clear how much work we were supposed to show)
This course is fast-paced but that is necessary to cover everything. It feels like a graduate-level course when it moves so quickly and requires so much.
nothing. This class is perfect.
The class moves quickly and is does not take well to even momentary lapses in attention. It would be easy to fall behind without doing supplementary reading or attending help sessions.
If possible structured meetings for students to work on weekly homework together.Reminder about the homework solution sections, once school gets busy its easy to forget that they're available!
None-- very well taught.
None in particular
The pace is too fast. Might be better to take more time on key concepts. Maybe even write on the board more.
Slides are too junked up. The good content gets lost among the clip art.

I would love a sheet with just a big list of the vocabulary organized by topic. I would love a sheet like the flow chart we got at the end of models to use but with more detail. I would also love more basic comprehension check questions on the homework like those that are used in the review sessions. A lot of the homework is completing tasks while the review questions test to see if you understand them. Peppering these questions into lecture more or assigning just a couple simple questions on the homework would have helped me make sure I got the Main Points and helped me connect the dots.

The aspect of this course that need improvement is the standardization of grading by all of the TAs. I received different grading for some of my homework with my other associates for the same answers but graded by different TAs.
There was some delay in getting questions about the midterm exam answered, which caused some anxiety as the due date approached.
Honestly I can't see any
his office hours
Instructor is a little fast in the class.
Lectures. Sometimes they were too fast to follow
TA's should be more aware of the concepts being covered that week.
I think it would be helpful if we could move just a little bit slower in class to help cement some material.
The amount of new content is a little bit overwhelming and it takes me a while to figure out to which extent I need to master a specific area.

It would be really helpful if first 10 mins of the class were spent quickly revising the previous concepts. That way, due to repetitive revisions, concepts will be better understood and students can remember them. Plus in stats, things cannot be understood in a standalone manner and hence, students will be better able to compare different topics and learn when and where to apply different concepts. I ve had 2-3 of my maths teachers do that, and I still remember most of those concepts.
None

I appreciate how much material JDRS wants to cover but at some point it just became too much and we were just speeding through material. Certainly the last month or so of classes became a bit of a blur and I didn't feel nearly as comfortable with the material as I did for the first part of the semester. I felt really prepared for the first midterm and fairly lost on the second midterm.
The pace of the course was slightly fast.
The speed with which complicated concepts are presented.
selection of the teaching assistants

The professor and the TAs are NOT very accessible during the semester, excluding the final period for the final project, to the majority of the class. The proceedure for signing up for professor office hours was very confusing, and usually filled up so fast due to the quantity of students that there was no way to ask for help in the course until the very end. The open hours where anyone could come ask for help from the professor were limited compared to the 1 on 1, and as a result I did not find a space to discuss issues with the professor or TAs 1 on 1.Course should really use R or statistical package that is used more widely in the field, as much convenience in later statistics analysis will come from software knowledge not just the concepts. Feel that because we used Minitab the knowledge gained in this course will not be as helpful for future research.

The pace of the course is very fast during the last 4 weeks, while it was fairly slow initially for simpler concepts. I think we could have used more time to learn more complex concepts, and gone over simpler statistics concepts (averages, standard deviation, etc.) faster.
The TAs should have more office hours.
The TFs were inconsistent in how they evaluated students.

I think the TAs should be more involved--for example when we are doing exercises in class, it would have been great to have them go around the room to answer questions. Also during days when we were working on final project (all crowded in CSSSI) it would have been great to have more than JRS there so everyone could get help sooner.
I think I would like a textbook for this course with some practice problems similar to the problem sets.

Slow down! It's impossible to form questions in class when you're moving so fast! Also, I think lots of people say this, but sometimes the humor can drown out the important stuff. It often felt like I was in elementary school. Also, we were often let out of class up to 20 minutes early. Why not slow down the lecture to allow for more questions and let us out on time?

The course moved too fast, it either should cover less topics with more detail or be spread out over two semesters. I could definitely say I need more training in statistics to be able call myself confident in the subject.
Some of the lectures were too fast-paced, however there are plenty of opportunities to receive clarification outside of class.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: There was no discussion or lab.
It was good
It was effective.
The homework solution sections and office hours were directly related to ongoing class content
Homework and course lectures were related, could be beneficial to have more example questions similar to the homework during the lectures.
NA
All of the materials and discussions were effective.
n/a
Professor Reuning-Scherer was very available with office hours and help on final projects, which was a huge advantage of this course.
Very effective and the professor was available
absolutely effective.
I found them very effective. Very well organized

Drop-in sessions are effective. I wasn't able to attend discussion this semester for another course at exactly the same time. Therefore I suggest hold discussion at different times probably biweekly for students with different schedules.
Very effective. The problem sets were great at keeping us on track.
No labs/discussion
the teaching assistants were not committed to the coursework and did not have time to explain questions
No discussion section.
N/A no lab sections. Office hours though were excellent for clarification on lectures and homework.
n/a
It was very effective and applicable.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: The TFs were not well-equipped to help with homework assignments.
Did not interact much with the TAs

It was excellent already. He was very responsive to any question that I have. He was very easy to reach or to access. He always provided answers and explanations on every question. Even in the last weekof the semester, he allocated many hours in Statlab to help us doing our homework. I took Stat in my undergraduate, and it was boring. The way Jonathan taught the class brought a very good atmosphere in learning statistic.
TA was also available. I have not been able to come up with a weakness
During office hours she sometimes couldn't explain concepts in a way that I could understand.
I worked with a number of the TAs over the semester and sometimes felt like they were struggling to explain the material as it related to the problem sets.
The TF was always punctual and took the time to explain concepts to us. I think she did a great job and the homework sessions were very helpful.
I did not interact with TAs

i primarily worked with Coco and she never really had time to explain things and sometimes she would just offer the answer instead of actually working through the problem with us. It just seemed like she did not have time for the class.

I did not seek one on one support from any of the TFs, so my only commentary pertains to grading. One strength is that they were all timely in grading and returning our assignments. A weakness is the lack of consistency across how many points were deducted for incorrect answers.

I think the TAs may have been overwhelmed by the sheer number of students in the class; it could be hard to find time to have them explain a concept in detail, but they did a good job trying to get around to everyone, and were very patient with all of our questions. I think it helped to have had taken the course before becoming a TA; Coco is really nice and very, very smart, but sometimes she wasn't able to address how a question fit into our coursework or understand where our questions were coming from, since she wasn't as familiar with the course material or with what we had or hadn't learned. This also made it harder for me to fit her explanations back into the course content.
Teaching fellows were unable to explain probability problems clearly.

I didn't go to a teaching fellow's office hours and the they were not at all involved in class, so the only interaction I had with them was through grades, which seemed like they varied quite a bit by TF.
Instructor: Emily Elizabeth Oldfield  I never met with the TA, but I thought her grading looked reasonable.
Instructor: Emily Elizabeth Oldfield  I thought her assistance on the homework was not at all useful. I left possibly more confused than I arrived and shifted to Coco for hw help thereafter.

Instructor: Emily Elizabeth Oldfield  Sometimes the TA's had a hard time explaining concepts in a way that I could understand; however, it is hard to teach to lots of different modalities and they tried their best!Emily is awesome. She is so helpful and nice and was great at helping students who were all worked up calm down and work through problems carefully.
Instructor: Emily Elizabeth Oldfield  My interaction with Emily was minimal, but as mentioned above, when I visited office hours, she was helpful.
Instructor: Emily Elizabeth Oldfield  Really helpful and organized.
Instructor: Emily Elizabeth Oldfield  My teaching assistant was helpful and challenged me to work out the problem rather than give me the answer directly.
Instructor: Jia Liu  More inclined to give answers than explain concepts
Instructor: Jia Liu  She can improve by discussing outside home work questions
Instructor: Jia Liu  Teaching assistant was very willing to help, but often times was not aware of the specific material we had covered that week.

Instructor: Jia Liu  Very helpful, but it would be good to teach how to solve homework problems rather than just showing solutions - in this aspect Emily Oldfield was more conducive to helping students to learn.

Instructor: Jia Liu  Coco was always very helpful and enthusiastic. She did not leave a student's side until they demonstrated that they understood the material. She could be even more helpful if she contextualized explanations more.
Instructor: Jia Liu  More clear explanation of point assessments

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Very important stuff. I'm an MEM but I did research over the summer and I'm so very glad I took the course. I'm now planning on taking Multivariate Stats in the spring and am genuinely excited for it.
Using it to provide a base of knowledge as opposed to any desire to "do" statistics professionally.
it is a good foundation course.
Good primer on stats
It's a really good fit if you want to do quantitative analysis.

I'm an undergrad, but I'm taking this to prepare for graduate school, and this class is extremely well taught and very useful. Not looking forward to taking statistics at grad school because I know it will never be as good as this one.

I had taken an undergraduate course in statistics, but it had been 7 years. I am planning on doing research over the summer and felt a refresher was necessary. This class went more in-depth than that previous class and the use of MiniTab was really useful in focusing less on theory and more on application.
Understanding the common statistical tools used for scientific analysis makes it easier to understand scientific journals/papers and to analyse personal research data.
Fills a measurements requirement for my MF degree and reinforces college-level statistics I took without minitab software
The regression analysis is especially applicable for any environmental research that I may have to undertake in the future.
This course will help me do my own statistical analysis for my research.
This course helps me to understand how to use statistical tools and analyses for my data.
It will be important for me to be able to read and interpret statistical data related to sustainability metrics. I think this course prepared me well for this.
This course was incredibly useful for learning the statistical tools to analyze the data for my undergraduate thesis. I imagine that it will be helpful for similar applications in the future.

I am an MESc, so having an understanding of statistics is very important. I know much more than when I started the course, though I still have a long way to go! Definitely have a good start from taking this class though.
Fits in my overall program and beyond the program as Stats is a lifetime tool
I had never taken statistics before and have no interest in taking advanced statistics but i find that my understanding of the course will help me in most of my other classes.
Very relevant to me. After taking this course, i can better understand implications of policies
This was my first class in statistics. It gave me the skills to be able to read case studies within the ES and understand what statistical methods were used, and why.

This material is very closely related to what I want to study and will be really valuable to my future studies. I have already had a statistics class before, which definitely helped me understand the material better.
I've already encountered many stats concepts in other courses. This course is extremely important as a foundation.
Helps with experimental design and overall approach towards research.
I wanted to have a good grasp on Stats concepts for either future research projects or for reading scientific papers.

As an Environmental Studies major, I believe that introductory statistics has improved my ability to interpret study results and data. Furthermore, this course will prepare me for the Five-Year Program for Yale College Students, to which I have applied.
As a baseline for understanding academic articles.
I work on modeling and so this class is integral to working with my data.

This course was crucial to the completion of my research, and was formatted perfectly to allow me to feel like I could master the material (in problem sets/midterms) and then apply it to my own dataset immediately after. Thank you!!
Very good intro to stats but doesn't use a relevant statistical package.
I am taking courses that require critical reading of primary literature. It's important to understand statistics to analytically read primary research.

I think understanding statistics is an essential foundational skill set. It's widely applicable across the sciences and business, and being conversant in statistics is a basic academic and job requirement.
Very well, I was also taking an ecology and biology course and this was very helpful in regards to understanding studies with statistics results etc.
I really felt I needed at least a basic stats background for a focus on policy and on the social sciences side of environmental management.
This was a great course for someone who had very little background in statistics. I think it will be useful for reading academic papers and understanding the statistical methods and references used.
I thought it was helpful and worthwhile.

Statistics is a powerful too for my major, environmental studies (with a specific social science/sociology focus). It is good for any major that intends to undertake rigorous analytic methodology in research, and I hope to be using statistical analysis for my upcoming senior project.
It is extremely applicable in any field.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I needed it for my research. I thought I remembered statistics from my undergrad course and I even got an exemption from the foundation, but I really needed a second look at the material. I'm very glad I took it.
see above.
Because I want to learn statistics.
to get a better understanding of regressions
I wanted to become better at statistics. I didn't have a deep understanding of statistical analysis.
Having never taken a statistics class before, I felt it was very important to get a basic understanding of the field.
Wanted to be better able to understand/analyze scientific papers/research.
requirement
Preparation for graduate school next year.
To gain tools I needed to work on research data I collected over the summer.
I took this course to refresh my stats background.
To learn statistics
I had never taken statistics in the past, and I wanted to improve my understanding of statistical analysis.
Foundation for reading documents with statistics in them and, possibly, to prepare for a joint business school curriculum.
Statistics is the language of science these days.
I aimed to review my knowledge on Statistic. Statistic is very important for dealing with data.
I took this course since it was a foundations course and I knew that understanding statistics is important regardless of what field I enter.
Please see my response to question 20.
I took this course in order to learn how to analyze my undergraduate thesis data.
To learn about statistics.
To be comfortable at Analyzing data, in the School program as well as in my professional career
To use it in my research.
Because quantitative skills are essential in today's job market.
I had never taken statistics before and have no interest in taking advanced statistics but i find that my understanding of the course will help me in most of my other classes.
As mentioned above to better understand the implications of the policies. This is one course that can be directly implemented in real life situations.
I don't have a strong statistics background and thought it would help me understand economics research
To better understand regression analysis.
I needed to review fundamental statistics material before going on to take more advanced statistics classes.
To strengthen quantitative skills
I don't have a lot of experience dealing with data and this course provides an overall understanding of data.
To be able to better analyze social science survey data.

To round out my scientific knowledge. I had already taken stats 3 years before (at an excellent college I'll point out) but needed to be reminded of many of the basics and we covered twice the material my college semester course did.
I took this course not only to become better acquainted with statistics, which is widely applicable, but also to adequately prepare for the Forestry School program.
I needed a refresher course in statistics as I had been out of school for a while and I thought it would be helpful for conducting research etc? over the summer.
I had never before taken statistics and I will need it in the future.
to refine my knowledge of statistics
Requirements, and to help me process my data (collected the prior summer)
To refresh my knowledge of statistics before beginning another academic degree.
To aid my data analysis.
See above.
Statistics may be important to my career path.
I elected to take this course because understanding statistics is an essential core skill set to most professions.
I wanted to refresh my understanding of statistics.
Because statistics are present in a lot of readings/ lab reports/ etc and its very useful to be able to understand it.
Please see the response to question 20.
I took this course to have a general working knowledge of basic statistics concepts for my future work in forestry and environmental science.
It was required, but I can see why it is required.
It was a foundation course, but I also thought it would help me understand stats better (even if I don't do a lot of my own data analysis, at least I'll understand where data is coming from).
To learn statistics for my senior research
This was a prerequisite for other courses
It received good reviews and I had yet to take statistics.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: YES.
yes
Yes.
Yes
YES!
Yes.
Yes
I certainly feel better about having exposure to statistical tests, but I still (and probably never will) be confident in my abilities with it.
Far more than anticipated. It's great. I learned a lot more than I had expected.
Yes.

Yes, they did! I'm glad I waited till 2nd year to take the class but it would have been alot easier to read and understand scientific journals if I had taken it as foundations courses in my first year.
Yes. The course is taught from a practical, rather than theoretical standpoint. This is very helpful from a management perspective.
Yes - exceeded even
Yes, but in general I don't feel extremely confident about my knowledge on statistics because the course was too fast.
Exceed.
Yes.
The knowledge/skills that I gained were beyond my expectations.
Yes, we covered a lot of material and learned more statistical concepts in this class than I would have in other stats classes.
Yes.
Yes
Yes.
Yes
Yes. even though I took Statistics in the past, I understand more from this course.
yes
yes
Very much
I am not as well-versed as I'd like to be, but I do understand statistical tools much better now.
Yes, far and beyond.
yes, definitely.
Yes
Yes, by the end of the course I'm able to do some simple analysis of data and know the parameters better.
Yes, it was great
Yes.
I originally had intended to take the 3 main stats classes while at FES but I will admit that I don't feel comfortable enough with the material we just covered to move onto those advanced classes.
Yes, I feel as if the concepts I have learned in this course will continue to benefit me throughout my academic and professional career.
Yes.
Yes.
yes! it was my favorite class
Yes, this class precisely met my expectations.
Yes, except for the software package.
Somewhat. However, the heavy reliance on MINITAB is not ideal because it is likely I won't have access to that kind of software in the future.
Yes they did - I feel more comfortable reading journal articles and can develop basic models using multiple regression.
Yes.
Yes. I'm now conversant in statistics, which was my objective.
Yes. I think I would have liked to have some things that we had to memorize, or at least were suggested to be memorized. That would make it easier to connect concepts throughout the course.
I feel like my skills from the first half or three-quarters of the class are strong; I am less confident about the last forth of material.
Yes, absolutely!
Yes.
Yes, though I think that we could have gone over some things in more detail and the TFs could have played a more active role.
The course certainly helped, though I my have to do some additional personal learning to strengthen my skills.
Yes
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: I chose not to work in groups
n/a
Working in a group saved my live!
More enjoyable to work in a pair for the final project. Good to bounce ideas off of each other.
Because I am better at writing and my partner is better at stats, I did more of the editing and she did more of the stats, so I didn't really learn any new skills on the project.
The advantages were fruitful discussion and task distribution.
n/a
Sharing knowledge, learning to get ideas across
Aside from better understanding and cooperation among group work, we build friendship as the most important thing I get.
it helped us delve into a common interest that we all shared and showed strengths and weaknesses among group members which is helpful.
I enjoyed and learn so much more from the group work as i have never had statistics in my life. I have learnt so much for my class mates.
We solved problems together based on our differing understandings/take aways from lecture
it's good to share thoughts but sometimes it can take extra time in an ineffective way because of too many different voices.
The option to work in a group for the final project was a great way to accomplish more work and analysis than working alone
Sharing of workload, opinions as well as different backgrounds giving new perspectives.

I always work in a group if possible, from problem sets to final projects. More fun and you learn more. There was a good rotating cast of classmates I worked with every week and it was good to have a team for the final project. Of course, group finals are hard b/c people prioritize their individual work over group work most of the time but having more hands on deck was good in the long run.
Working in a group provided for clarification and collaboration on course material.
I think it was helpful to work on a group project but the process could be better streamlined if the instructor were to set earlier deadlines.
It was good to compare notes, as everyone had different strengths in terms of understanding the material presented in class.
the advantages were that when my team mates had the time, the workload was easier and understanding the material was easier because we could help each other
I worked with one other person for the final project, and found that I was much more creative in developing our research questions because of the back-and-forth dynamic.
The group project was a good way to apply some of the things we learned to a real-world data-set.

I learned a lot from my fellow group mates. Everyone had a unique way of understanding and explaining complex concepts, so being able to puzzle through our final project together gave us all the opportunity to learn the material in a new way.
I did feel it was helpful to discuss misunderstandingswith classmates and the final project was excellent way to bounce ideas and concepts off one another.

I enjoyed the group because we all have different strengths and could contribute to different parts of the prject without having to do the whole thing. It is also nice because if you work well together, you can help each other understand difficult parts of the project. However, group work is always hard to coordinate and sometimes people work differently or have different ideas of what they want the project to be, which can be frustrating.
n/a

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: TAKE IT.
Take it. Review the lecture materials frequently before you forget it.
This is an opportunity to learn statistics really well, don't miss it!
Go to the Q&A sessions even if you don't have specific questions formulated!
Professor's help sessions are definitely worth your time.
Prepare to work hard and fast

All undergrads should take this class instead of the other class because then you get JRS for the entire semester instead of half. Such a good class! Although there is a project, which is slightly annoying, but well worth it.
Take it.

Take this class if you need to learn or brush up your stats tools, especially if you'll be working with your own data (or other people's analysed data) now and or in the future. Taking it in first or second year is a question of retaining the knowledge for post summer use and perhaps motivation.
Maybe use the text book too for practice problems and an additional voice to complement the notes.I only used the notes.
Definitely join a team for working on homework and for preparing for the exams.

The class is pretty fast paced with regular problem sets. Class lectures also move very quickly, so come caffeinated and well-fed and ready to learn.JDRS is a dedicated professor who really knows his stuff. He definitely goes into the nitty gritty of why and how various statistical tools work the way they do, however, so be prepared for that. You will start to be able to tease out which parts of the lecture are critical and which parts are background information.By the end, you will have a comprehensive, albeit surface level, understanding of basic statistical tools. This will allow you to delve deeper, as desired.Minitab is very helpful -- that is what we use throughout the course -- but is expensive to own as a non-student. I'm hoping that learning that program won't be a waste!
Take it! Jonathan is a great teacher and this course is a good fit for someone new to the world of statistics or just looking for a refresher.
Do all of the homework by yourself before discussing with the TA or the Instructor.
Take it!

I would suggest buying one of the optional textbooks and reviewing the content prior to the lectures. Since it is a large class and the pace is pretty quick, having a basic understanding of the concepts ahead of time would help in retaining information.
Try to read the suggested readings as much as you can, as they definitely help reinforce the material that is introduced in class.
Take this course if you want to learn basic statistics.
The problem sets in the middle of the course take a long time (2-6 hours), so plan accordingly! The problem sets at the end of the course take less time, so it gets better.
Strongly recommend
Even though you got basic statistics in the past, just take this course. You'll find new fascination with statistics and numbers.

Inclass time is essential to understanding what is going on. JDR goes very fast so you can't miss a second of it or you will be lost for the remainder of the hour. Working regularly makes the class very bearable in terms of workload and it is overall a very interesting class (and a great professor).
do homework on time and work with friends.
I strongly recommend students to take this course irrespective of what background they come from. Very useful.
Drop in on the lecturer's office hours
Take full advantage of TA office hours, and clarify any difficulties with professor as they arise.
This is a great class to take: definitely stay on top of the readings and the problem sets, but it is definitely a must-take class for everyone in any field.
Take part in study groups but don't get dependent on it.
It's a great class, take it!
Come with questions!

If you're not sure if you should take this class or a different one, go meet with JDRS during shopping period. He will quickly help you decide. If you're like me and took a good college class on intro statistics, I still recommend taking this class b/c he covered more material than my college class did and it was good to have a re-grounding before more advanced work or a research project.
Be sure to ask questions the moment that they arise. Also, take advantage of office hours!
Class is fast paced but fun! Don't' miss class and get the homework done on time. Definitely attend the office hours and help sessions if you need clarity on something.
Keep up with your level of understanding, because each successive topic builds on previous ones.
use the notes...everything you need for the homework's and assignments is there!
Do all of the problem sets!

Don't take it as a refresher if you've already taken a basic stats course. Go for a course that uses R or some other research methods course.If you haven't taken any stats this course is essential and Jonathan is one of the best professors I've seen who can make stats painless.
Start your problems sets early! Don't wait until the night before to begin
Decide if you want to learn statistics and only take the course if you're serious about learning the subject. Keep up with the lectures and homework because this course moves quickly.
This is a basic statistics class that covers a lot of material in a short amount of time. The professor is exceptional and always available for extra help. I highly recommend it.

The end of the course seems to move more quickly than the beginning. It's very easy to input data into MiniTab and look at results without much understanding... it's good to use book to make sure you do understand!
Get a good textbook and ask the professor for some practice problems (with answers in the back) that are similar to the problem sets. Also go to the TAs/ CSSSI for help- its very useful.

Try the more biology-centric textbook (I have heard from others it's very useful, and mine was sometimes too similar to the course notes to offer the different perspective and clarification I was looking for). Re-read notes and try and get help as early as possible, and maybe from other students in addition to the TAs and Professor.
See answer to question 15.

Go to class and be engaged and participate! Read the notes he gives you. You don't necessarily have to take notes in class, just listen and watch what the professor does so that you can repeat it on your homework. Go to office hours, JDRS is very approachable and helpful.
Go to the professor's and TA's office hours - they are eager to help.
Before and after lectures, read up on the subjects! I understood things better if I spent time out of class reading on my own, not just working on problem sets.
GO TO OFFICE HOURS AS OFTEN AS YOU CAN AND THIS CLASS WON'T HAVE TO BE SO DIFFICULT FOR YOU.
I would advise taking it if you want to achieve a basic understanding of statistics. The instructor is superb and the material is worthwhile.
